title: Psalms Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms Chapter 20 according to the text?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 states that this is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: From where does the Psalm ask for help to be sent?
questions.correctAnswer: From the sanctuary
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:2 requests help to be sent from the sanctuary.

questions.question: According to Psalms 20:3, what does the Psalmist ask God to remember and accept?
options: All thy offerings and burnt sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: All thy offerings and burnt sacrifice
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:3 asks God to remember all offerings and accept burnt sacrifices.

questions.question: What is granted according to Psalms 20:4?
questions.correctAnswer: According to thine own heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:4 says God grants according to the heart's desire and fulfills counsel.

questions.question: In Psalms 20:5, what do they say they will rejoice in?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:5 declares rejoicing in salvation and setting up banners in God's name.

questions.question: What does Psalms 20:6 say God saves?
questions.correctAnswer: His anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:6 states that the LORD saves his anointed and hears him from heaven.

questions.question: According to Psalms 20:7, some trust in chariots and horses, but what do we remember?
options: The name of the LORD our God
questions.correctAnswer: The name of the LORD our God
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:7 contrasts trust in chariots and horses with remembering the name of the LORD.

questions.question: What is the outcome for those who trust in chariots and horses according to Psalms 20:8?
options: They are brought down and fallen
questions.correctAnswer: They are brought down and fallen
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:8 states that those who trust in chariots and horses are brought down and fallen.

questions.question: What does Psalms 20:8 say about those who trust in the LORD?
options: We are risen, and stand upright
questions.correctAnswer: We are risen, and stand upright
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:8 contrasts the fallen with those who stand upright because of the LORD.

questions.question: What is the final plea in Psalms 20:9?
options: Save, LORD: let the king hear us when we call
questions.correctAnswer: Save, LORD: let the king hear us when we call
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:9 ends with a plea for salvation and for the king to hear their call.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 20:1 asks the LORD to hear the people in the day of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 clearly states a request for the LORD to hear in the day of trouble.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 20:4, God will not fulfill the counsel of the heart.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:4 says God will fulfill all counsel according to the heart's desire.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 20:6 mentions that God hears his anointed from the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:6 says God hears from his holy heaven, not from the earth.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 20:2: 'Send thee help from the ______, and strengthen thee out of Zion;'
questions.correctAnswer: sanctuary
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:2 requests help to be sent from the sanctuary.

questions.question: Complete this phrase from Psalms 20:5: 'We will rejoice in thy ______, and in the name of our God we will set up our banners:'
questions.correctAnswer: salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:5 states 'We will rejoice in thy salvation'.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 20, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in times of trouble?
options: The LORD hears and defends us in trouble
We should rely solely on our own strength
Troubles mean God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD hears and defends us in trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 teaches that the LORD hears us in the day of trouble and defends us, reassuring believers to trust God's protection. This is supported by verses 7 and 9 which contrast trusting God rather than earthly powers.

questions.question: How does Psalms 20:2 encourage believers to seek help in spiritual disciplines and church life?
options: By sending help from the sanctuary and strengthening from Zion
By isolating oneself from the church
By relying on personal wisdom alone
By seeking help only from friends
questions.correctAnswer: By sending help from the sanctuary and strengthening from Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:2 emphasizes that God sends help from the sanctuary and strengthens us from Zion, highlighting the importance of spiritual connection and fellowship in the community of faith.

questions.question: What does Psalms 20:3 teach about the importance of personal devotion and worship?
options: Remembering offerings and accepting burnt sacrifices pleases God
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering offerings and accepting burnt sacrifices pleases God
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:3 calls believers to remember their offerings and sacrifices, indicating the value of sincere worship and devotion in spiritual discipline.

questions.question: A believer is praying for guidance on a major life decision. According to Psalms 20:4, what biblical principle should they trust?
options: God grants according to the heart and fulfills counsel
questions.correctAnswer: God grants according to the heart and fulfills counsel
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:4 shows that God grants according to the desires of the heart and fulfills wise counsel, encouraging believers to seek God’s guidance in their decisions.

questions.question: How does Psalms 20:5 inspire joy and gratitude in the context of salvation and prayer?
options: Rejoice in salvation and trust God to fulfill petitions
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice in salvation and trust God to fulfill petitions
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:5 encourages rejoicing in salvation and trusting God to fulfill our petitions, promoting a heart of gratitude and faith.

questions.question: What assurance does Psalms 20:6 give about God's care for His anointed, and how does this relate to perseverance through trials?
options: God saves and hears His anointed with strength from heaven
God abandons His people in hardship
Success depends on human effort alone
God is silent in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God saves and hears His anointed with strength from heaven
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:6 assures that the LORD saves His anointed and hears them from heaven with strength, encouraging believers to persevere trusting in divine help.

questions.question: How does Psalms 20:7 contrast different types of trust, and what practical lesson does this teach about faith?
options: Some trust in chariots and horses, but we trust in the name of the LORD
Trust in wealth is the best security
Trust should be placed in human leaders alone
questions.correctAnswer: Some trust in chariots and horses, but we trust in the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:7 contrasts trusting in earthly power versus trusting in God’s name, teaching believers to rely on God’s faithfulness rather than human strength.

questions.question: A believer is feeling defeated by life’s challenges. How does Psalms 20:8 encourage them regarding their spiritual posture?
options: Though others fall, we are risen and stand upright
Giving up is the only option
questions.correctAnswer: Though others fall, we are risen and stand upright
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:8 offers encouragement that while others fall, believers who trust God are raised and stand firm, promoting perseverance and hope.

questions.question: What is the significance of the prayer in Psalms 20:9 for personal and communal devotion?
options: Save, LORD; let the king hear us when we call
questions.correctAnswer: Save, LORD; let the king hear us when we call
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:9 is a communal prayer for salvation and hearing from God, emphasizing the power and importance of united prayer and intercession.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 20, trusting in earthly resources like horses and chariots is as reliable as trusting in the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:7 clearly distinguishes between those who trust in horses and chariots and those who trust in the LORD, showing that trusting God is the reliable choice.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 20 teaches that God listens to prayers from heaven with the power of His right hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:6 states that the LORD hears His anointed from His holy heaven with the saving strength of His right hand, affirming God's attentive and powerful response to prayer.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "We will rejoice in thy _______, and in the name of our God we will set up our banners."
questions.correctAnswer: salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:5 says, "We will rejoice in thy salvation," highlighting joy and celebration rooted in God’s saving power.

questions.question: How does Psalms 20:1 emphasize humility and dependence on God in daily life and work ethic?
options: The LORD hears in trouble and defends in His name
Self-reliance is the key to success
Ignore God’s help in daily tasks
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD hears in trouble and defends in His name
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 reminds believers that God hears and defends in times of trouble, encouraging humility and dependence on Him in all areas of life including work.

questions.question: What lesson about prayer and stewardship can be drawn from Psalms 20:3’s mention of offerings and burnt sacrifices?
options: God values sincere offerings and devotion
questions.correctAnswer: God values sincere offerings and devotion
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:3 highlights the importance of remembering offerings and sacrifices, teaching believers about faithful stewardship and wholehearted worship.

questions.question: How can Psalms 20:4 guide a believer in family life and parenting when making decisions?
options: Trust that God grants desires and fulfills counsel
Ignore God’s guidance in family matters
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God grants desires and fulfills counsel
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:4 teaches that God grants according to the heart and fulfills counsel, encouraging prayerful and God-centered decision-making in family life.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 20.

questions.question: In Psalms 20:1, who is invoked to hear in the day of trouble and defend?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 explicitly states 'The LORD hear thee in the day of trouble; the name of the God of Jacob defend thee,' indicating the LORD is the one invoked.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'sanctuary' and 'Zion' mentioned in Psalms 20:2 in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: They represent the earthly seat of divine help and strength
They are metaphors for the human heart
They are foreign lands allied with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the earthly seat of divine help and strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:2 says, 'Send thee help from the sanctuary, and strengthen thee out of Zion;' Zion is the mountain of Jerusalem, the spiritual and political center, while the sanctuary is the temple, the earthly dwelling of God’s presence, highlighting divine help coming from these holy places.

questions.question: Psalms 20:3 contains the word 'Selah.' What is the best scholarly interpretation of 'Selah' in this Psalm?
options: A musical pause or reflection point
questions.correctAnswer: A musical pause or reflection point
questions.explanation: In Psalms 20:3, 'Selah' likely indicates a pause for meditation or musical interlude, emphasizing the importance of remembering and accepting offerings and sacrifices.

questions.question: According to Psalms 20:4, what does the LORD grant and fulfill?
options: According to thine own heart and all thy counsel
questions.correctAnswer: According to thine own heart and all thy counsel
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:4 clearly says, 'Grant thee according to thine own heart, and fulfil all thy counsel,' indicating a personal and divine alignment with the desires and plans of the worshiper.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'setting up banners' in the name of God as mentioned in Psalms 20:5?
options: It symbolizes rallying under God's protection and victory
It refers to military conquest through human power
It is a pagan ritual borrowed from surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes rallying under God's protection and victory
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:5 says, 'in the name of our God we will set up our banners,' which in ancient Near Eastern warfare meant rallying troops under a standard, here signifying confidence in divine salvation rather than human strength.

questions.question: In Psalms 20:6, the term 'anointed' refers to whom, and how does this relate to messianic typology?
options: The king or chosen leader, foreshadowing the Messiah
The pagan kings of surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: The king or chosen leader, foreshadowing the Messiah
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:6 states 'the LORD saveth his anointed,' which traditionally refers to the king (such as David), but in Christian interpretation, it foreshadows the ultimate Messiah, God's anointed Savior.

questions.question: How does the contrast between trusting in chariots and horses versus remembering the name of the LORD in Psalms 20:7 reflect the Psalm’s theological theme?
options: It contrasts human military power with divine trust
It promotes the superiority of chariots over horses
It encourages political alliances with foreign armies
It condemns all forms of warfare
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts human military power with divine trust
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:7 contrasts those who rely on chariots and horses (military strength) with those who trust in the LORD’s name, emphasizing faith in God over military might.

questions.question: According to Psalms 20:8, what is the outcome for those who trust in the LORD compared to their enemies?
options: They rise and stand upright while enemies fall
questions.correctAnswer: They rise and stand upright while enemies fall
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:8 states, 'They are brought down and fallen: but we are risen, and stand upright,' highlighting the victory and stability granted to those who trust in God.

questions.question: In Psalms 20:9, what is the purpose of calling on the LORD to save and let the king hear us?
options: To invoke divine help and assurance for the king’s success
To request the king to lead a feast
To ask the king for military weapons
questions.correctAnswer: To invoke divine help and assurance for the king’s success
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:9’s plea 'Save, LORD: let the king hear us when we call' shows the community requesting God's saving intervention and communication with their king for victory.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 20 is structured primarily as a communal prayer for the king’s victory in battle.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The Psalm repeatedly petitions for the LORD to defend, strengthen, and save the king, indicating a communal prayer for his success in conflict (Psalms 20:1-9).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the literary device used in the parallelism between trusting chariots and horses versus remembering God's name in Psalms 20:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Antithetic parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:7 uses antithetic parallelism by contrasting two opposing ideas: trust in military power versus trust in God’s name.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 20:6 states, 'Now know I that the LORD saveth his _____; he will hear him from his holy heaven.'
questions.correctAnswer: anointed
questions.explanation: The verse specifically uses the word 'anointed,' referring to God’s chosen leader or king (Psalms 20:6).

questions.question: How does the theme of divine help in Psalms 20 relate to the broader biblical motif of God as a warrior?
options: It echoes God's role in Exodus as the defender of Israel
It contradicts God's peaceful nature in the New Testament
It focuses only on human military tactics
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes God's role in Exodus as the defender of Israel
questions.explanation: The Psalm’s plea for divine help and salvation by God’s right hand recalls God’s warrior role seen in Exodus where He fights for Israel (Psalms 20:6).

questions.question: Which Hebrew term in Psalms 20 is associated with a liturgical or musical instruction, and what is its significance?
questions.correctAnswer: Selah - indicating pause and reflection
questions.explanation: The word 'Selah' in Psalms 20:3 is a liturgical term likely indicating a pause or musical interlude for contemplation.

questions.question: True or False: The repeated invocation of the LORD’s name in Psalms 20 emphasizes the ancient Israelite belief in the power of God's name to protect and save.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 and 20:7 emphasize remembering and invoking the LORD’s name, reflecting the belief that God's name embodies His protective power.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 20:1, whose name is invoked to defend the one in trouble?
questions.correctAnswer: The God of Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:1 specifically mentions the 'name of the God of Jacob' as the defender in the day of trouble. This emphasizes God's covenant faithfulness to Jacob's descendants, consistent with Genesis 28:13 and Exodus 3:15 where God reveals Himself as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

questions.question: What does Psalms 20:2 say God will send from the sanctuary to help and strengthen?
questions.correctAnswer: Help and strength
questions.explanation: The verse states that God will send help from the sanctuary and strengthen from Zion, symbolizing divine aid and power. This aligns with Isaiah 41:10 and Psalm 46:1 where God is depicted as a helper and strength in times of trouble.

questions.question: In Psalms 20:3, what offerings does God remember and accept?
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt sacrifice
questions.explanation: The psalmist petitions God to remember all offerings and accept the burnt sacrifice, symbolizing complete dedication (Leviticus 1:9). This reflects the Old Testament sacrificial system pointing typologically to Christ's ultimate sacrifice (Hebrews 10:12).

questions.question: What does Psalms 20:4 say God will grant to the petitioner?
options: According to their own heart and counsel
questions.correctAnswer: According to their own heart and counsel
questions.explanation: God is asked to grant according to the individual's heart and fulfill all counsel, emphasizing God's sovereignty and personal relationship with the believer. This is consistent with Proverbs 3:5-6 and Psalm 37:4 where God aligns with the desires of the righteous.

questions.question: What is the community's response to salvation in Psalms 20:5?
options: Rejoicing and setting up banners in God's name
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoicing and setting up banners in God's name
questions.explanation: The verse declares rejoicing in salvation and setting up banners in God's name, symbolizing victory and public declaration of faith. This imagery resonates with Exodus 17:15 and 2 Samuel 18:18, where banners signify triumph granted by God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 20:6, from where does the LORD hear His anointed?
questions.correctAnswer: His holy heaven
questions.explanation: The LORD hears His anointed from His holy heaven with saving strength, highlighting God's transcendence and immanence. This matches Isaiah 63:9 and 1 Kings 8:30, portraying God's attentive presence toward His chosen king.

questions.question: What do some trust in, according to Psalms 20:7, contrasting with the trust in the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Chariots and horses
questions.explanation: The psalm contrasts trusting in chariots and horses with trusting in the name of the LORD, condemning reliance on military might rather than divine power. This theme is echoed in Psalm 33:17 and Jeremiah 17:5.

questions.question: What is the outcome for those who trust in chariots and horses in Psalms 20:8?
options: They are brought down and fallen
questions.correctAnswer: They are brought down and fallen
questions.explanation: The psalm states that those trusting in chariots and horses are brought down and fallen, while the faithful stand upright, underscoring the futility of trusting in human strength rather than God. This is supported by Psalm 20:7 and Isaiah 31:1.

questions.question: What plea is made to the LORD in Psalms 20:9?
options: Save, LORD: let the king hear us
Bless us with peace and joy
questions.correctAnswer: Save, LORD: let the king hear us
questions.explanation: The psalm concludes with a plea for salvation and for the king to hear the people when they call, reflecting trust in God's protection over the anointed leader. This is consistent with 2 Samuel 22:3 and Psalm 18:50.

questions.question: What theological truth is underscored by the repeated emphasis on God hearing the anointed from heaven with saving strength (Psalms 20:6)?
options: God is sovereign and actively involved in salvation
Salvation is dependent on human effort
The anointed must act without divine aid
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign and actively involved in salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 20:6 highlights God's sovereign power and personal involvement in delivering His anointed, consistent with Romans 8:31 and Ephesians 1:19-20 where God's strength is at work for believers.

questions.question: How does Psalms 20:4 reflect the doctrine of God's providence?
options: God grants according to the heart and fulfills counsel
God punishes all desires of the heart
God only grants what is asked publicly
questions.correctAnswer: God grants according to the heart and fulfills counsel
questions.explanation: This verse teaches that God sovereignly grants requests aligned with the heart and counsel, showing divine providence in guiding human plans, paralleling Proverbs 16:9 and James 4:13-15.

questions.question: What messianic theme is present in Psalms 20:6 concerning 'his anointed'?
options: God saves His chosen king by His mighty hand
The anointed is saved by his own strength
The anointed must conquer through armies
questions.correctAnswer: God saves His chosen king by His mighty hand
questions.explanation: The reference to 'his anointed' points to the king chosen by God, a foreshadowing of Christ the Messiah, who is saved and empowered by God's hand, as seen in Acts 4:27-28 and Psalm 2:2-4.

questions.question: What does the setting up of banners in the name of God (Psalms 20:5) symbolize doctrinally?
options: Public declaration of victory and divine protection
questions.correctAnswer: Public declaration of victory and divine protection
questions.explanation: Banners signify victory granted by God and public acknowledgment of His protection, paralleling Exodus 17:15 and 2 Samuel 18:18 where banners represent God's triumph.

questions.question: How does the contrast between trusting in horses and trusting in the LORD (Psalms 20:7) address apologetic concerns about faith and reason?
options: Faith in God surpasses reliance on military or human strength
God is indifferent to human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: Faith in God surpasses reliance on military or human strength
questions.explanation: The psalm teaches that true security comes from trusting in God rather than human means, affirming the rational trust in divine providence found in Isaiah 31:1 and Proverbs 3:5-6.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implicit in the confidence that 'we are risen, and stand upright' (Psalms 20:8)?
options: The ultimate victory and resurrection of the faithful
The loss of all earthly kingdoms
The final destruction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The ultimate victory and resurrection of the faithful
questions.explanation: The standing upright contrasts defeat with victory, pointing forward to resurrection hope and final triumph, consistent with 1 Corinthians 15:55-57 and Revelation 19:11.
